results.abstract: Small businesses must jump through hoops to secure slots at airports, where snow delays increase sales, but those who have done it say it is worth the effort.

results.adx_keywords: Airports;Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants;Entrepreneurship;Small Business

results.abstract: The company announced that it has dropped the price of a package featuring its Rift headset and Touch controllers by 25 percent to $598 from $798.

results.abstract: An Indian state, aiming to crack down on lavish weddings in an effort to narrow the gap between rich and poor, is capping the number of guests.
results.byline: By AYESHA VENKATARAMAN and NIDA NAJAR

media.copyright: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media.caption: Garima Pant, a bride, being escorted to the wedding hall by her relatives and bridal party in New Delhi in 2014. Jammu and Kashmir State in India has imposed new regulations capping the number of guests at weddings and engagement parties.

results.adx_keywords: Weddings and Engagements;Kashmir and Jammu (India);India;Marriages;Legislatures and Parliaments
results.title: Here Comes the Bride. Now Count the Rest.

results.abstract: Corporations have crisis management firms at their behest. Small-business owners have to rely on their own wits to respond to political animosity.

media.copyright: Matt Roth for The New York Times
media.caption: Nicole Morgenthau, owner of Finch Knitting & Sewing Studio, in Leesburg, Va. When Ms. Morgenthau received an email from a Trump supporter threatening a boycott of her store, she posted the letter and her reply on Facebook, leading to an outpouring of support and an increase in business.

results.adx_keywords: Boycotts;Small Business;United States Politics and Government;Trump, Donald J;E-Commerce
results.title: How Small Firms Can Defuse a Political Threat and Blunt a Boycott

results.abstract: The two companies agreed to reduce the price Verizon will pay for Yahoo’s internet businesses to account for the impact of two huge data breaches.

media.caption: A Verizon store in Chicago. Verizon will pay $4.48 billion for Yahoo, about $350 million less than it initially offered after security breaches that were disclosed last year.

results.adx_keywords: Computers and the Internet;Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures;Verizon Communications Inc;Yahoo! Inc
